labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Improve "system-mount-point" naming and description
issues.author: lana-wu
issues.body:
From Sergio on WG adoption comments:

I have only one comment regarding the **"system-mount-point" grouping and container**. If the intention of this grouping/container is to have a place holder for some configuration parameters , I do not think the name is good since it seems related to "schema mount" as it seems not the case. Frankly speaking the YANG description does not help too much to understand the scope so my proposal would be:

  **1.  Improve the description
  2.  Change the name consequently to the new description**

Sergio, 01 August 2024

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/inventory-yang/49iY8eTKBS65XhEIamyFp0P8TuQ/

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: We don't have anymore "system-mount-point" in the draft

issues.title: Italo's comments on the YANG model improvements during WG adoption
issues.author: lana-wu
issues.body:
1.  I have seen you have added appendix A but it is not very clear what is the purpose of this Appendix (at the first glance it appears a copy of the YANG model which we developed in the CCAMP WG I-D): do we really need this appendix?
  2.  What is the purpose of the node-name?

If it is intended to report the system-hostname, let's consider whether this attribute belongs to this model or to the network-element in the inventory model. If it belongs to this model, I would suggest to align the attribute name and description with the definition of system-hostname

If it is intended to be a generic name attribute, we may remove it as proposed by Olga during the meeting today

  1.  What is the purpose of the system-mount-point empty container?

If the intention is to mount technology-specific attributes, I am wondering whether using a "multi-inheritance" approach, as described in section 4.1 of RFC8345, could be used to specify technology-specific attributes and navigation from topology to inventory within a single topology instance.

  1.  What is the purpose of the tp-name?

I think we can remove it as proposed by Olga during the meeting today

  1.  Why the tp-name is RO while the node-name is RW?
  2.  What is the purpose of the leaf-list interface-name?

If the intention is to navigate from topology to interface model, what about using the ietf-tp-interface-reference-topology model in draft-ietf-ccamp-if-ref-topo-yang?

This I-D is a CCAMP WG draft because we have spun it off from the MW topology model after thinking that the requirement to navigate from topology to interface is technology-agnostic.

It has presented to Netmod WG in IETF 118 and still looking for an home WG where to be progressed: minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00.md ([ietf.org)<https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/118/materials/minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00>](http://ietf.org)%3Chttps//datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/118/materials/minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00%3E)

  1.  I would suggest to provide some text to address the question from Aihua during the meeting today.

Italo

[](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/inventory-yang/wrqY1H7wGf-E2i2Uj10pBQMQ_gA/)

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body:
Candidate proposal:

**1)      I have seen you have added appendix A but it is not very clear what is the purpose of this Appendix (at the first glance it appears a copy of the YANG model which we developed in the CCAMP WG I-D): do we really need this appendix?**

[Bo Wu] Thank for catching this. The comparison conclusion should be added that the modeling approach in CCAMP WG I-D seems redundant and causes these duplicate nodes at each layer. Defining a new "network-types" can avoid this and can be flexibly combined with other  layer topologies.

**2)      What is the purpose of the node-name?**

If it is intended to report the system-hostname, let's consider whether this attribute belongs to this model or to the network-element in the inventory model. If it belongs to this model, I would suggest to align the attribute name and description with the definition of system-hostname

If it is intended to be a generic name attribute, we may remove it as proposed by Olga during the meeting today

[Bo Wu] Agree with your suggestion as Olga pointed out to remove this and consider moving  "system-hostname" to base inventory model.

**3)      What is the purpose of the system-mount-point empty container?**

If the intention is to mount technology-specific attributes, I am wondering whether using a "multi-inheritance" approach, as described in section 4.1 of RFC8345, could be used to specify technology-specific attributes and navigation from topology to inventory within a single topology instance.

[Bo Wu] This node is defined for the augment target for obtaining some general configuration information, for example, ACL policies in the enterprise campus networks.

**4)      What is the purpose of the tp-name?**

I think we can remove it as proposed by Olga during the meeting today

[Bo Wu] OK.

**5)      Why the tp-name is RO while the node-name is RW?**
[Bo Wu] Good catch. Will correct this.

**6)      What is the purpose of the leaf-list interface-name?**

If the intention is to navigate from topology to interface model, what about using the ietf-tp-interface-reference-topology model in draft-ietf-ccamp-if-ref-topo-yang?

This I-D is a CCAMP WG draft because we have spun it off from the MW topology model after thinking that the requirement to navigate from topology to interface is technology-agnostic.

It has presented to Netmod WG in IETF 118 and still looking for an home WG where to be progressed: minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00.md ([ietf.org)<https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/118/materials/minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00>](http://ietf.org)%3Chttps//datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/118/materials/minutes-118-netmod-202311071200-00%3E)

[Bo Wu] Thanks for information. Will take this into account.

**7)      I would suggest to provide some text to address the question from Aihua during the meeting today.**
[Bo Wu] Agree to add text to clarify mapping relationship between nodes and NEs, also with other links and tps.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @lana-wu, what is the status of this one? I guess most are addressed.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> [@lana-wu](https://github.com/lana-wu), what is the status of this one? I guess most are addressed.

I think points 6) and 7) are still open. All the other points have been addressed.

comments.author: lana-wu
italobusi
comments.body:
> [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) [@boucadair](https://github.com/boucadair) For points 6)，I do not think “ietf-tp-interface-reference-topology” model is the right approach. because interface-ref is device local. Therefore, here in the inventory topology model, we follow the definition as Layer 2 Network Topologies rfc8944 and Layer 3 Network Topologies rfc 8346. And it's necessary to map between the termination point, the physical port, and the specific interface, right?
> 
> point 7) Current YANG model design has a one-to-one relationship between the abstract node and the physical NE, as well as between the termination point and the link. I think the model looks quite straightforward. We can clarify this if you think it's necessary

It seems that these two comments require mode discussion so I have created two new issues (i.e., #16 and #17) to track them

You can either close this issue (leaving issues #16 and #17) or keep this issue open and defined issues #16 and #17 as sub-issues of this issue

No strong opinion on my side

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body: Close the issue and track the remaining issues #16 and #17

issues.title: Whether the location reference should be added
issues.author: lana-wu
issues.body:
An independent location list (e.g. site, room, rack) has been defined in draft-wbbpb-ivy-network-inventory-location. 

Do the inventory topology directly reference the location or indirectly reference the location through NEs?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @lana-wu, this can be accessed through NEs. No need to have duplication, IMO.

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body: I also support this approach. We can close this issue.

issues.title: discuss whether/where  to put this text
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
> , i.e., the path name of a
>            corresponding interface data node on the containing
>            node is reminiscent of data type interface-ref defined
>            in RFC 8343.  It should be noted that data type
>            interface-ref of RFC 8343 cannot be used directly,
>            as this data type is used to reference an interface
>            in a datastore of a single node in the network, not
>            to uniquely reference interfaces across a network

(used to be in the yang, but the reasoning is better discuss (if needed) in the narrative text.

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body:
That text is to explain why “interface-name” should be used, not “interface-reference” of RFC 8343 device model. The text is borrowed from "interface-name" of L2 topology (RFC 8944) and L3 topology (RFC8346). 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8944#name-layer-2-topology-yang-module
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8346#autoid-6

There is also a relevant CCAMP draft: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-ccamp-if-ref-topo-yang-01 defines tp-to-interface-ref.
I was wondering if our document could cover this defined in draft-ietf-ccamp-if-ref-topo-yang.

issues.title: reusable groupings
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: We do gave many reusable groupings, but many of them are used once. I suggest we simplify that.

issues.title: policy mount
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: The need for such anchor for future augmentation need to be described.

comments.author: lana-wu
comments.body: @boucadair I was thinking that this might be related to specific NDT scenarios, such as verifying whether network-level ACL/QoS/routing policies conflict. Perhaps we can remove the "policies-target-point" node and give some augmentation example in the appendix.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: No need to remove it, then. Please suggest some text to be added to the narrative part to explain the intended use. Thanks.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
ACL/QoS/routing policies conflict looks to me quite technology-specific.

While the requirement looks valid, why addressing it is in the scope of the network inventory topology and not of some technology-specific topologies?

If it is applicable to more than one technology, another option is to create a generic "policy topology" which can be used with IP or other technology-specific augmentations

issues.title: reference-back from inventory to topo
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: We should explain how navigation from inv to topo and vice versa can be done. Do we need explicit refs in both directions?

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
Every association is inherently bidirectional: if A is associated with B then, by definition, is B inversely associated with A

Modelling explicitly in the YANG models the associations as bidirectional will cause the YANG models to provide plenty of redundant information with the complexity in keeping all the redundant data aligned (and the risk of creating inconsistencies)

The issue becomes even more complex if we consider that if A is associated with B and B is associated with C, also A is indirectly associated with C.

Some applications would need to know/operation on the indirect A to C association: does this means that also these indirect associations shall be explicitly modelled in YANG?

Taking this approach to the extremes would lead to create YANG data models for every possible query to the Datastore increasing the volume of duplicated information

IMHO, the YANG data models (in particular the standard ones) should provide the minimum information which is needed to be exchanged on an interface. Any possible query that is needed to provide the data requested by each application can be implemented in the client.

If it is desired to have this query being performed by the server, maybe we better define some language to create views/queries for YANG models.

Some initial raw thoughts have been exchanged in a side meeting during IETF 121 and submitted as a possible issue to be addressed in YANG-next: https://github.com/netmod-wg/yang-next/issues/151

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
A similar issue has been discussed a couple of weeks ago during the network inventory call: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/issues/3#issuecomment-2622500990

During the call some people expressed some concerns with the child-component-ref which are similar to the one I have expressed above

However, removing the child-component-ref would have some other issues that need to be addressed so the issue/discussion in that context is still open

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
the association is bidir, but depending on the use case one may start from inventory and then find a pointer to a topo, but other uses may the other way around. 

Having an explicit ref back does not mean that we need to have redundant content. 

Independent whether we have explicit refs, my main concern is that we need to explain the two-way navigation.

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
I have received the same requirement internally, and being able to navigate in both directions is required. 

However, I agree with @boucadair that what needs to be clarified is which are the relations.

I my opinion (and this is how we have implemented internally)  we miss one relationship when trying to navigate from Hardware inventory to topology.

A link in the topology is built with two termination points. Those termination points are abstractions for *logical* interfaces. Those interfaces might be really a subinterface (e.g. a VLAN of an interface), the full interface, a full LAG.... The interface is then associated to a hardware port. 

So... the relationship should be termination point (topology) <--> logical sub interface (when required) ( maybe found in logical inventory?) <--> logical interface (ethernet or LAG) ( maybe found in logical inventory?) <--> port (found in logical inventory).

Breakout could even complicate the relation more....

However... as you can clearly see there one piece of the puzzle missing for the relationship I am proposing.. You might want to create a "shortcut"...

We should consider also SIMAP for the relationship among models.... to avoid adding extra overhead to the base models....

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> the association is bidir, but depending on the use case one may start from inventory and then find a pointer to a topo, but other uses may the other way around.

IMHO, every association modelled in YANG with a leafref is inherently bidirectional

Could you provide an example of a YANG leafref representing a unidirectional association?

> Having an explicit ref back does not mean that we need to have redundant content.

Can you elaborate a bit  more on this statement?

IMHO, if a TP instance foo has a leafref to a port instance bar (representing the port instance supporting TP instance foo), a leafref for port instance bar to the TP instance foo (representing the TP instance supported by the port instance bar) looks duplicated/redundant information

> Independent whether we have explicit refs, my main concern is that we need to explain the two-way navigation.

Even if all the associations are inherently bidirectional, I fully agree to provide text in the I-D to describe the two-way navigation

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> A link in the topology is built with two termination points. Those termination points are abstractions for _logical_ interfaces. Those interfaces might be really a subinterface (e.g. a VLAN of an interface), the full interface, a full LAG.... The interface is then associated to a hardware port.
> 
> So... the relationship should be termination point (topology) <--> logical sub interface (when required) ( maybe found in logical inventory?) <--> logical interface (ethernet or LAG) ( maybe found in logical inventory?) <--> port (found in logical inventory).
> 

I am not sure we need to manage the interfaces in the network models

IMHO, the topology model should report the TPs representing the Ethernet interfaces, the logical VLAN sub interfaces and the LAG bundled interfaces.

I am not sure the current ETH/L2 topology models provide enough information to associate the TPs representing the VLAN sub interfaces with the underlaying Ethernet interface but this is an issue which can be addressed in those topology models.

RFC 8795 supports bundled links and therefore already supports the association between the TP representing a LAG interface and the underlaying TPs representing the aggregated Ethernet interfaces

The association with a port component in the inventory model applies only to the lowest level TP in this hierarchy which, in some cases, it can be the TP associated with the Ethernet interface. In other cases, this association applies to a TP supporting the TP associated with the Ethernet interface

The current YANG model design is very flexible to cover any case since it is not bound to any specific type of TP

> Breakout could even complicate the relation more....
> 

Based my current understanding, in case of breakouts there are more TPs associated with the same port component. Some additional information (e.g., something like the "channels" in OpenConfig) can/should also be provided to describe how the resources within the port component are associated with different interfaces/TPs

See also https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/pull/76

The current working assumption (the PR is still under review) is that the base inventory model will just provide information about whether the port can support or not breakout but it will not provide any information about whether a port is configured as a breakout or trunk port. The latter information is better provided by this model.

IMHO, we can add some examples to this I-D to describe these cases

issues.title: Need to associate a link with a cable
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
This issue has been discussed on the mailing list but I think not yet addressed

See: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/inventory-yang/MxdA8RUlwuRnIbLKfgR_NFZRB0Y/

An companion issue has been created for the passive inventory model: See also https://github.com/aguoietf/draft-ygb-ivy-passive-network-inventory/issues/2

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
My reading is that an explicit ref is not needed.

If after investigation (in the passive model or other extensions) it appears that a link is needed, my suggestion is that this handled as part of these models. We have an issue for providing this modularity guidance in the the base.

issues.title: Purpose of the leaf-list interface-name
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
What is the purpose of the leaf-list interface-name?

If the intention is to navigate from topology to interface model, what about using the ietf-tp-interface-reference-topology model in draft-ietf-ccamp-if-ref-topo-yang?

This I-D is a CCAMP WG draft because we have spun it off from the MW topology model after thinking that the requirement to navigate from topology to interface is technology-agnostic.

It has presented to Netmod WG in IETF 118 and still looking for an home WG where to be progressed: [minutes-118-netmod](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-118-netmod-202311071200/)

See issue #2

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> [@italobusi](https://github.com/italobusi) [@boucadair](https://github.com/boucadair) For points 6)，I do not think “ietf-tp-interface-reference-topology” model is the right approach. because interface-ref is device local. Therefore, here in the inventory topology model, we follow the definition as Layer 2 Network Topologies rfc8944 and Layer 3 Network Topologies rfc 8346. And it's necessary to map between the termination point, the physical port, and the specific interface, right?

See: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-topology/issues/2#issuecomment-2644718138

I am still confused

While, I am not aware of any implementation of RFC 8343 at the northbound of a network controller, I have heard different opinions about whether RFC 8343 can or not be implemented at the northbound of a network controller.

If RFC 8343 is not implemented at the northbound of a network controller, what can the client of the network controller do with an interface name which is not referencing any other information provided by the controller?

The current description is also quite ambiguous since the network controller can report the interface-name but can also report a void string (e.g., "Hallo World") and the client of the network controller has no way to understand what it is actually reported in this string.

Moreover, in RFC 8944 and RFC 8346, there is only one interface-name while in the current YANG model it is a leaf-list.

issues.title: Relationship between nodes and NEs
issues.author: italobusi
issues.body:
I would suggest to provide some text to address the question from Aihua during the meeting today.

See issue #2 

This issue refers to the following discussion at [minutes-120-ivy](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-120-ivy-202407241630/):

> Aihua: At moment we only have 1 to 1 relationship between nodes and
> elements. Do we support the case where an abstract node can be supported
> by several physical NEs (or the reverse) or is it always 1 to 1?
> 
> Bo: Currently we just consider 1 to 1 mapping, because it applies to
> most cases.
> 
> Italo: Perhaps look at some text in the CCAMP draft which states the
> mapping between network nodes and elements can be many to 1. One node in
> physical topology and another groups the physical nodes avoid making the
> mapping more complex.
> 
> Bo: I agree.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
> point 7) Current YANG model design has a one-to-one relationship between the abstract node and the physical NE, as well as between the termination point and the link. I think the model looks quite straightforward. We can clarify this if you think it's necessary

See: https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-topology/issues/2#issuecomment-2644718138

This is the text in the [draft-ietf-ccamp-network-inventory-yang](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-ccamp-network-inventory-yang/) I was mentioning:

> Network topology is a logical abstraction based on hardware inventory objects. The abstraction may be based on technology requirements (e.g., layer 0 or layer 1 resources) or on some specific requirements (e.g., for path computation or service provisioning).
> 
> Therefore the relationship between hardware inventory objects and network topology objects can be 1:N (N>=1).
> 
> Taking the Optical technology as example, an Optical Transport Network (OTN) Network Element (NE) can be installed with several kinds of boards, including an Ethernet client signal switching board, a line board which is used for OTN layer switching. This line board may also be used as a starting point for the WDM layer. In terms of technologies, this OTN NE supports multi-layer network topology connections, so that it should appear in L0, L1 and L2 network topology.

As described in section 3.2:

> A TE node represents one or several nodes, or a fraction of a node, which can be a switch or router that is physical or virtual.

My understanding is that the question of Aihua was how to navigate from an abstract node which is supported by multiple physical NEs and the physical NEs.

I am noting that the current text in [draft-ietf-ccamp-network-inventory-yang](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-ccamp-network-inventory-yang/) is not as explicit as I though and we have discussed: https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/ietf-network-inventory/issues/33#issuecomment-1323894609

In a nutshell, each node in the network inventory topology maps with a single physical NE in the network inventory. The association between the abstract node and the physical NEs is described by associating the abstract node with the corresponding nodes in the network inventory topology. The underlay topology relationship has been already defined in RFC 8795 for this purpose.

The 1:N association was described to cover the case where a NE supports nodes in different layers (e.g., an OTN node in the OTN topology and a WDM node in the WDM topology).

Thinking further, we can follow the same approach above and define only a 1:1 mapping between the nodes in the network inventory topology and the physical NEs in the network inventory. The association between the OTN and WDM nodes and the physical NE can be described by associating the OTN and WDM nodes with the corresponding node in the network inventory topology. 

I think some text clarifying these two points would be useful for the readers and implementers.

reviews.author: lana-wu
reviews.body: The updated abstract text looks good.

reviews.author: lana-wu
reviews.body: Text improvements of the main text by Med.

comments.author: italobusi
comments.body:
@boucadair : you can also re-use the port-ref grouping for associating a TP with a port

https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/blob/c3a9cd69bce8b5ce23888e1c9b82db9f4e0c994f/yang/ietf-network-inventory.yang#L133-L157

If you wish to align this module with the recent changes defined for modelling the breakout ports, you can also considering re-using the channel-ref grouping for associating a TP with one or more breakout channels of a breakout port:

https://github.com/ietf-ivy-wg/network-inventory-yang/blob/c3a9cd69bce8b5ce23888e1c9b82db9f4e0c994f/yang/ietf-network-inventory.yang#L159C12-L199
